name: #0 Genoise Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #1 Fruit Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #2 Chiffon Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #3 Pound Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4 Genoise Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #5 Sponge Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #6 Chiffon Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #7 Genoise Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #8 Red Velvet Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #9 Opera Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #10 Sponge Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #11 Flourless Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #12 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #13 Sponge Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #14 Pound Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #15 Upside Down Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #16 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #17 Carrot Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #18 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #19 Pound Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #20 Pound Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #21 Yellow Butter Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #23 Flourless Cake

name: #24 Sponge Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #25 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #26 Genoise Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #27 Opera Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #28 Upside Down Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #29 Hummingbird Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #500 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #1077 Opera Cake

Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #1176 Fruit Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #1177 Sponge Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #1178 Red Velvet Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #1179 Pound Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #1180 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #1181 Red Velvet Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #1182 Yellow Butter Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #1183 Chiffon Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #1184 Devil's Food Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #1185 Yellow Butter Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #1186 Pound Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #1195 Opera Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. name: #1199 Flourless Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #1200 Carrot Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #1201 Upside Down Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #1370 Flourless Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #1371 Genoise Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #1372 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #1373 Devil's Food Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #1374 Hummingbird Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #1375 Hummingbird Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #1376 Fruit Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #1377 Angel Food Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #1381 Chiffon Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #1382 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #1383 Sponge Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #1384 Devil's Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #1385 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #1386 Genoise Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. name: #1391 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #1392 Pound Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. name: #1393 Upside Down Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #1470 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #1471 Hummingbird Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #1472 Angel Food Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #1473 Flourless Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. name: #1475 Upside Down Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #1476 Chiffon Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #1477 Opera Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #1478 Flourless Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #1565 Pound Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #1566 Upside Down Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #1572 Flourless Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #1573 Angel Food Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #1574 Hummingbird Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #1575 Upside Down Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. name: #1587 Carrot Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #1588 Hummingbird Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #1589 Opera Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #1958 Red Velvet Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #1959 Yellow Butter Cake

name: #1967 Fruit Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. name: #1968 Flourless Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #1969 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #1970 Genoise Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #1971 Flourless Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #2055 Devil's Food Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #2056 Genoise Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #2057 Devil's Food Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #2058 Hummingbird Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #2059 Hummingbird Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #2060 Carrot Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #2061 Upside Down Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #2062 Hummingbird Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #2063 Chiffon Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. name: #2064 Yellow Butter Cake

name: #2065 Sponge Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. name: #2066 Flourless Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. name: #2067 Genoise Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #2068 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #2070 Upside Down Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #2071 Flourless Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #2072 Carrot Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #2073 Red Velvet Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #2074 Upside Down Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #2075 Upside Down Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #2076 Angel Food Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. name: #2079 Flourless Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #2442 Flourless Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #2445 Flourless Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #2446 Carrot Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #2447 Hummingbird Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #2448 Genoise Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #2449 Chiffon Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #2450 Upside Down Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #2451 Chiffon Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #2452 Devil's Food Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #2454 Pound Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #2455 Flourless Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #2735 Fruit Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #2736 Angel Food Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #2737 Genoise Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #2738 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #2739 Hummingbird Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #2740 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #2741 Hummingbird Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #2742 Upside Down Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #2743 Upside Down Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #2744 Chiffon Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. name: #2746 Flourless Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #2926 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #2927 Flourless Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #2928 Red Velvet Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #2929 Red Velvet Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #2930 Chiffon Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #3120 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3121 Genoise Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #3122 Chiffon Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #3123 Opera Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3126 Devil's Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #3149 Red Velvet Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3220 Fruit Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3221 Devil's Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3222 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #3223 Devil's Food Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #3224 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3225 Red Velvet Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3226 Opera Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3227 Pound Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3228 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #3229 Opera Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3230 Fruit Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3231 Devil's Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #3232 Upside Down Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #3233 Devil's Food Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #3234 Fruit Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #3235 Red Velvet Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #3236 Devil's Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3237 Upside Down Cake

name: #3238 Pound Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #3239 Flourless Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #3240 Hummingbird Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3241 Pound Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #3242 Angel Food Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #3243 Fruit Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #3416 Genoise Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #3417 Angel Food Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3418 Opera Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #3419 Upside Down Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #3420 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #3421 Opera Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #3422 Opera Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3423 Yellow Butter Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #3430 Sponge Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3431 Red Velvet Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #3432 Sponge Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #3433 Genoise Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #3434 Genoise Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #3435 Chiffon Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #3436 Pound Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3437 Red Velvet Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #3514 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3515 Opera Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #3516 Flourless Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3517 Devil's Food Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #3518 Fruit Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #3519 Flourless Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3520 Opera Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #3611 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #3612 Chiffon Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3613 Flourless Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3614 Angel Food Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #3615 Hummingbird Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #3616 Upside Down Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #3617 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #3618 Flourless Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #3619 Chiffon Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #3620 Fruit Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #3621 Chiffon Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #3622 Pound Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #3623 Flourless Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #3804 Opera Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #3805 Carrot Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #3806 Chiffon Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. name: #3807 Sponge Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. name: #3808 Devil's Food Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #3815 Opera Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #3816 Chiffon Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3817 Pound Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #3818 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. name: #4310 Angel Food Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #4580 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #4581 Devil's Food Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #4582 Opera Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #4583 Devil's Food Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #4584 Chiffon Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #4585 Devil's Food Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #4586 Genoise Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #4587 Angel Food Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #4768 Devil's Food Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4769 Genoise Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #4770 Genoise Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #4771 Carrot Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #4772 Upside Down Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #4773 Devil's Food Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #4776 Chiffon Cake

name: #4777 Genoise Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #4778 Opera Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #4779 Hummingbird Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4780 Devil's Food Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #4781 Red Velvet Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #4782 Carrot Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4783 Flourless Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. name: #4785 Devil's Food Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.
