name: #4868 Sponge Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4869 Fruit Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #4870 Genoise Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4871 Flourless Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #4872 Red Velvet Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #4873 Red Velvet Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #4874 Yellow Butter Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #4875 Devil's Food Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #4876 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #4877 Devil's Food Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #4878 Fruit Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #4879 Devil's Food Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #4880 Carrot Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #4881 Genoise Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #4882 Devil's Food Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #4883 Chiffon Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #4884 Pound Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #4885 Sponge Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #4965 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #4966 Flourless Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #4968 Opera Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #4969 Opera Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. name: #4970 Red Velvet Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #4971 Sponge Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #4972 Opera Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #4973 Flourless Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #4974 Angel Food Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #4975 Hummingbird Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. name: #5059 Hummingbird Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #5060 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #5061 Hummingbird Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. name: #5062 Upside Down Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #5352 Opera Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #5353 Hummingbird Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #5354 Sponge Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #5355 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #5356 Devil's Food Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #5357 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #5358 Devil's Food Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #5359 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #5360 Upside Down Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #5361 Red Velvet Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #5362 Carrot Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #5363 Opera Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #5364 Hummingbird Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #5365 Sponge Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #5366 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #5367 Genoise Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #5368 Chiffon Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #5448 Yellow Butter Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #5449 Red Velvet Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #5450 Fruit Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #5451 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #5452 Chiffon Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #5453 Devil's Food Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #5455 Fruit Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. name: #5456 Pound Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. name: #5457 Flourless Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #5458 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #5459 Upside Down Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #5460 Genoise Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #5461 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #5468 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #5469 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #5836 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #5837 Carrot Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #5838 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #5839 Hummingbird Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #5840 Genoise Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #5841 Yellow Butter Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #5843 Chiffon Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. name: #5844 Carrot Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #5845 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #5846 Chiffon Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. name: #5848 Opera Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #5850 Genoise Cake

name: #6319 Sponge Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #6320 Hummingbird Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. name: #6321 Pound Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. name: #6322 Devil's Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #6812 Fruit Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #7222 Angel Food Cake

name: #7489 Hummingbird Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. name: #7490 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. name: #7494 Hummingbird Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #7495 Sponge Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #7496 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. name: #7504 Pound Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #7505 Upside Down Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #7587 Flourless Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #7588 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #7589 Carrot Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #7590 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #7591 Flourless Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #7592 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #7593 Fruit Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #7594 Upside Down Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #7595 Yellow Butter Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #7596 Yellow Butter Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #7597 Sponge Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #7598 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #7599 Sponge Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #7600 Angel Food Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #7601 Genoise Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #7602 Sponge Cake

name: #7604 Pound Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #7684 Hummingbird Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #7685 Devil's Food Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #7686 Carrot Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #7687 Red Velvet Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #7688 Sponge Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #7689 Opera Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #7690 Carrot Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #7691 Red Velvet Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #7692 Genoise Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #8071 Upside Down Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #8072 Fruit Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #8073 Yellow Butter Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #8074 Upside Down Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #8075 Chiffon Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #8078 Flourless Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #8079 Flourless Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #8080 Pound Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #8081 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. name: #8082 Chiffon Cake

name: #8130 Genoise Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #8650 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #8651 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #8652 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #8653 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #8654 Upside Down Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #8655 Genoise Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #8656 Chiffon Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #8657 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #8980 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #9342 Pound Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #9343 Sponge Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #9344 Pound Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #9345 Angel Food Cake
description: Fluffy white cake is layered with a fruit and nut filling and topped with a pillowy meringue type frosting. The origin of the cake is somewhat in dispute, but it’s believed to have been created in the southern part of the United States.

name: #9346 Upside Down Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #9347 Carrot Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #9348 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.

name: #9349 Fruit Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #9350 Flourless Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #9351 Lady Baltimore Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #9352 Fruit Cake
description: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

name: #9353 Angel Food Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #9354 Carrot Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #9356 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #9359 Flourless Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #9360 Red Velvet Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #9572 Flourless Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #9573 Angel Food Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #9635 Pound Cake
description: Universally loathed and joked about, this holiday staple is full of dried or candied fruit, nuts, and spices. Once cooked, the cake is wrapped and soaked in a spirit like brandy or rum. (Despite the jokes, we think it's very delicious.)

name: #9636 Carrot Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #9637 Pound Cake
description: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

name: #9638 Upside Down Cake
description: The classic version of this butter style cake is traditionally made with pineapple, but can be made with many varieties of fruits, including plums, peaches, blueberries, or pears. The toppings are spread on the bottom of the pan, often with butter and sugar, and then topped with cake batter. After cooking, the cake is turned out so that the fruit is facing up.

name: #9639 Pound Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #9640 Devil's Food Cake
description: This category includes both baked (think cheese cake or flourless chocolate) or unbaked (like mousse or unbaked cheesecakes) varieties. Typically very rich because of the high fat content, these cakes may or may not have a bottom crumb crust.

name: #9641 Yellow Butter Cake
description: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

name: #9642 Angel Food Cake
description: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

name: #9643 Angel Food Cake
description: The classic southern oil cake is flavored with banana, pineapple, pecans, lots of warm spices, and topped with a tangy cream cheese frosting. Created in Jamaica and originally called "Doctor Bird Cake,: this confection made its way Stateside sometime in the 1960s.

name: #9644 Pound Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #9645 Hummingbird Cake
description: This cake is made "devilish" by the addition of chocolate in the form of cocoa powder. Extra baking soda causes the crumb to have more air bubbles, giving it a light and airy texture. This rich cake is frosted with either chocolate frosting or buttercream.

name: #9650 Devil's Food Cake
description: The lightest of the light, angel food cake is made with only whipped egg whites for leavening and has no added fat. Baked in a special angel food cake pan, it’s often cooled upside down (in the pan) to help maintain the airy texture. The loads of sugar in an angel food cake give it a chewy and sponge-like texture.

name: #9651 Fruit Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #9652 Angel Food Cake
description: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

name: #9653 Chiffon Cake
description: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

name: #9654 Sponge Cake
description: Chiffon cake is a cross between a sponge and oil cake. The addition of oil gives it a richness similar to a shortened cake, and whipped egg whites and baking powder make it light and airy.

name: #9655 Fruit Cake
description: The history of this type of cake is a bit muddled. One thing we do know, however, is that its thin layers of coffee-soaked almond cake are sandwiched between an espresso-flavored buttercream, a bittersweet chocolate ganache, and topped off with a second rich chocolate ganache. Light but rich, this pastry is a real showstopper.
